required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Oronasopharyngeal Suction Versus Simple Nose and Mouth Wiping in Term Newborns
clinical_study.official_title: Newborn Resuscitation: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Oronasopharyngeal Suction Versus Simple Nose and Mouth Wiping in Term Newborns

brief_summary.textblock: Until recently, bulb or catheter oronasopharyngeal suctioning (ONPS) of all the infants, including vigorous infants in the delivery room, has been featured as a standard of newborn care. The 5th edition of the Newborn Resuscitation Program (NRP) has minimized the recommendation for routine suctioning of infants following delivery, provided they are not depressed or in need of immediate resuscitation. However, this new alternative recommendation was based on a small randomized trial and other lower level evidence rather than evidence from larger trials. The NRP Textbook cautions against vigorous suctioning because of the resultant apnea or bradycardia. Furthermore, suctioning may delay other more important steps of resuscitation. Thus, it is necessary to compare the alternative recommended practice, i.e. simple wiping of the mouth, to determine if it has equivalent efficacy and a favorable side effect profile compared to suctioning.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean respiratory rate over the first 24 hours of life
primary_outcome.description: Respiratory rates measured every 8 hours during the first 24 hours after birth

secondary_outcome.measure: Apgar Scores at one minute of age
secondary_outcome.description: Independent assignment of Apgar Scores at one minute of age
Number of newborns with tachypnea as defined by respiratory rate greater than 60 breaths per minute
Need for delivery room resuscitation including suctioning, intubation, positive pressure ventilation, chest compressions, and/or medication

secondary_outcome.measure: Admission to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit
secondary_outcome.description: Needing admission to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit

secondary_outcome.measure: Oxygen saturations prior to discharge from hospital
secondary_outcome.description: Measurements of oxygen saturations in the well baby nursery prior to discharge home

secondary_outcome.measure: Apgar score at 5 minutes of age
secondary_outcome.description: Independent assignment of Apgar score at 5 minutes of age

arm_group.description: Bulb suctioning of mouth and nose immediately after delivery
Gentle wiping of mouth then nose with soft cloth

intervention.description: Bulb suctioning of the mouth then the nose immediately following delivery
Gentle wiping of mouth then nose with a soft cloth immediately following delivery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Inborn neonates at the UAB hospital with gestational age greater than or equal to 35 weeks.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Major birth anomalies or where a decision to institute comfort care only has been made antenatally
- Significant resuscitation efforts are anticipated prior to delivery
- Nonvigorous infants with meconium stained amniotic fluid

responsible_party.investigator_title: Fellow Instructor, Department of Pediatrics, Division of Neonatology
